Bringing the Environmental Justice For All Act to the House floor for a vote and advancing other longstanding asks from environmental justice communities would be a welcome start.

Now that the debate over this #DirtyDeal is over, I stand ready to work constructively with my colleagues on other permitting legislative efforts that can accelerate the clean energy transition, while also protecting the already overburdened.

There is a lot of work to do to keep moving forward with the Biden administration‚Äôs momentum on tackling climate change and environmental injustices. We don‚Äôt have time to waste on unnecessary shutdown standoffs.
Having to vote for a bill that would worsen that status quo by gutting public input and fast-tracking dangerous projects like the Mountain Valley Pipeline would have been unconscionable.
All across the country, poor communities, communities of color, and Indigenous communities have been repeatedly burned by polluting industries‚Äô shortcuts and broken promises.

But I‚Äôm even more grateful to the hundreds of environmental justice communities, organizations, and leaders who took a stand against this dirty deal and called it what it was‚Äîanother slap in the face after decades of abuse.

Taking the #DirtyDeal permitting rider out of must-pass government funding is the right decision and I‚Äôm grateful to my colleagues for making it.
